questions.question_text: A high-security defense installation recently begun utilizing large guard dogs that bark very loudly and excitedly at the slightest provocation. Which of the following types of controls does this BEST describe?

discussion.content:
Preventive controls attempt to prevent an incident from occurring. 
Detective controls attempt to detect incidents after they have occurred. 
Corrective controls attempt to reverse the impact of an incident. 
Deterrent controls attempt to discourage individuals from causing an incident
Dunno bout you but I wouldn't wanna mess with that dog so A

questions.question_text: A customer calls a technician and needs to remotely connect to a web server to change some code manually. The technician needs to configure the user's machine with protocols to connect to the Unix web server, which is behind a firewall. Which of the following protocols does the technician MOST likely need to configure?

comments.content: Lol. How do you know the provided answer is correct? Did they give you the answer key after?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer is correct.
SSH used for general purpose connects

comments.content:
HTTPS is more for web pages.
Remoting on is done via SSH
he can try it on other pc i guess lol
Wouldn't the dev need HTTPS to be able to test the web page to make sure the changes made worked?

discussion.content: Why A and not C?

questions.question_text: A security analyst is assessing a small company's internal servers against recommended security practices. Which of the following should the analyst do to conduct the assessment? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Verify alignment with policy related to regulatory compliance
choices.B: Confirm adherence to the company's industry-specific regulations
choices.C: Review the company's current security baseline
choices.E: Run an exploitation framework to confirm vulnerabilities

discussion.content: My answer for this is B & C. " Baseline is what servers SHOULD have applied, and industry-specific regulations are the external recommendations the question is asking about."
isn't an exploitation framework a little bit extreme?

comments.content: agreed, this could potentially interrupt day to day uptime
it doesnt say that it cant be intrusive. An exploitation framework would give the most information

discussion.content: Although I'm not sure which two are the correct answers, I'm pretty sure E is not. Even a vulnerability scan makes more sense than running an exploit framework, which is way too aggressive for this scenario.
Yes, BC make the most sense. Ty MJ for the clarification.

Answer A and D
A security analyst is assessing a small company's internal servers against recommended security practices. (A) research what recommended security practices are at there
 
Verify alignment with policy related to regulatory compliance (D) check the company policies to be in compliences

Although I may not agree with it, the correct answers (at least on the Security + Exam) are A & D - verified. Do not try to gain any type of understanding from this poorly worded question/answer(s). Just select A & D and move on. I'd post a screen shot if I could.
Focus current internal status and baseline before external regulations.
The provided answers are correct
I would go with A & C which means A is the recommended security practices and C is the company's current config

comments.content: you would run an exploit against a system just to confirm it's vulnerable, many exploits if run incorrect will cause BSOD. Try running eternalblue against Windows7 in most cases it causes a BSOD, do that on a file server or domain controller and you're in trouble.

discussion.content: The given answers are correct. PLEASE do not cause confusion by providing wrong answers.
The assessment is being performed against recommended security practices, which means comparing the company's security baseline against the industry's.
Provided answers are correct.

If you notice, A,B & D are very similar answers. 
I guess provided answers are correct.

comments.content:
I agree, A and C
The analyst is assessing a small company's internal servers against recommended security practices.
In other words, he is comparing current security baseline (C) with recommended security practices (A)

Google what benchmarks are and how testing is done to achieve benchmark. You would never configure stuff to how they were during a benchmark.
Answers look correct.
First you say B and C/D in your first comment now it's A and C?...Don't trust this guys responses...prob a comptia agent

discussion.content:
A and C
(A) Platform benchmark: comparison against industry best practices. 
(C) Security baseline: represents the minimum security settings that must be adhered to.
Not (E) Exploitation Framework: A means of running intrusive penetration tests. We need an “assessment” not an exploitation.
Not (B) or (D) - the question mentions nothing about regulations or regulatory.
Keywords: to conduct the assessment. (B) Confirm adherence to industry-specific regulations and (C) review current baseline. But B and D are pretty much the same thing.
Sorry, i meant C, E

I'll go for B, D. 
I think the keyword on this one is : assessment.
Vulnerability assessment (VA) is a methodology for determining the vulnerability of an asset or assets at risk of being lost, taken, damaged, or destroyed. As such, the VA can be used as a tool for managing threats, or if you prefer, managing the risk that accompanies threats. A Gap analysis is a useful tool when deciding upon strategies and tactics. The process consists of baselining the present state and comparing this to a desired or “target” state.

questions.question_text:
Joe recently assumed the role of data custodian for this organization. While cleaning out an unused storage safe, he discovers several hard drives that are labeled
`unclassified` and awaiting destruction. The hard drives are obsolete and cannot be installed in any of his current computing equipment. Which of the following is the BEST method for disposing of the hard drives?

comments.content:
You can't wipe them because they're obsolete (i.e., very old and are not compatible with newer technology). Because of this, you can't confirm what data the drive actually contains. It could be mislabeled and actually contain company secrets. Since you can't access the data to verify what it is, it's always best to default to the most protective action - in this case destroying the drive.

Technically, degaussing the drive should also render it unusable; however, data may be forensically recovered. So smashing it to pieces is the best answer.

Again, why isn't this relevant?
"...labeled "unclassified" and awaiting destruction. The hard drives are obsolete and cannot be installed in any of his current computing equipment."
Why got to the trouble of specifiying this if the answer isn't «B», «Wipe»?

Degaussing also always assumes that it's not an SSD, because degaussing a SSD will have no effect. Just something to keep in mind. I hate that the CompTIA questions never clarify what hard drive we're talking about but to be on the safe side, I always assume it's an SSD when I see these kind of questions.

discussion.content:
There was another question on the test (Jan. 24, 2020) about hard disk data destruction. The options included, Degaussing, and Shredding, the other options were not as viable. I picked Shredding. 
""Hard drive degaussing erases all of your information using a magnetic field but leaves small amounts of data behind. However, hard drive shredding completely destroys the drive and is considerably less expensive.""

D.
If you need to destroy a physical storage device, then you may want to think about shredding it or pulverizing it. This uses machinery to break up the components themselves and completely destroying the storage device. You can do the same thing yourself if you have a drill or a hammer. You can drill directly through all of the platters, rendering them unreadable.

Shredding or pulverizing a hard drive uses specialized high-powered equipment to turn a drive into scrap and is one of the most common forms of physical destruction. Other methods include drilling holes in a drive, hammering a drive, or even shooting a drive.
Why not burning, that would be by far the best . you grantee that it will not be recovered in any circumstances.

comments.content:
According to Darril: "Burning: Many organizations burn materials in an incinerator.
Obviously, this can be done with printed materials, but isn’t as
effective with all materials."

choices.A: Add the following rule to the firewall: 5 PERMIT FROM:ANY TO:ANY PORT:53
choices.D: Remove the following rule from the firewall: 30 DENY FROM:ANY TO:ANY PORT:ANY
choices.B: Replace rule number 10 with the following rule: 10 PERMIT FROM:ANY TO:ANY PORT:22
choices.C: Insert the following rule in the firewall: 25 PERMIT FROM:ANY TO:ANY PORTS:ANY

discussion.content:

Now that's out the way the answer is A. Users are unable to connect to remote site and A allows DNS which is port 53.The rest won't do anything for connection issues to remote sites. A final answer
This was a tricky question though I can see why it would not be SSH, since SSH is not used encrypt HTTP

comments.content: This question was not tricky at all. SSH has nothing to do with connecting to websites. SSL/TLS is used to encrypt websites. You are missing a DNS server in this configuration
